questions.text: A dermatologist is explaining to a patient the importance of various skin structures in maintaining the skin's barrier function. She mentions a specific part of skin cells that contributes to the waterproof barrier, which prevents water loss and the entry of pathogens. Which component of the skin cells is most directly responsible for this critical barrier function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lamellar bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lamellar bodies in the epidermis are essential for the skin's barrier function as they release lipids that prevent water loss and protect against external pathogens.

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

questions.text: All of the following are secondary skin lesions except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wheal

questions.text: In a dermatology lecture, medical students are learning about characteristic histopathological features of various skin conditions. One feature of interest is the presence of microabscesses. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with microabscess formation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lichen planus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen planus is characterized by a lichenoid tissue reaction and does not typically feature microabscess formation, a finding more commonly associated with psoriasis, dermatitis herpetiformis, and sometimes mycosis fungoides.

questions.text: During a clinical skills session, a medical student notices that a patient with circular areas of patchy hair loss on their scalp also has irregularities on their nails. The student is asked to identify the nail finding most commonly associated with this type of hair loss. Which nail finding would be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nail pitting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nail pitting is a common finding in patients with alopecia areata, reflecting the systemic nature of autoimmune conditions that can affect both the skin and its appendages.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about significant hair shedding that began several months after she experienced a high fever and was diagnosed with COVID-19. Which condition is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Telogen effluvium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stressors such as severe infection, patients may present with telogen effluvium, a condition characterized by diffuse hair shedding that is usually self-limited and resolves over time as new hair growth occurs.

questions.text: A 16-year-old teenager is brought to the clinic by her mother, who has noticed several bald patches on her daughter's scalp. The teenager admits to a habit of pulling out her hair when she feels stressed. Physical examination reveals multiple non-scarring alopecia areas with different hair lengths within the patches. There are no signs of scaling or inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichotillomania

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose trichotillomania, which presents with irregular patches of incomplete, non-scarring hair loss and hair of varying lengths within the patches, often due to repetitive pulling of hair in response to stress

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, reporting a 3-month history of a mildly painful, swelling on his scalp. The mother mentions the family has a pet dog at home and the child often plays with it. On examination, the lesion is inflamed, raised, and has purulent discharge. Based on the patient's history and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kerion is an inflammatory tinea capitis, in a child with a prolonged history of a painful, swollen lesion on the scalp, particularly when there is a history of contact with pets, which can be carriers of the dermatophyte fungi causing the condition.

questions.text: A patient present with flat-topped violaceous papules and thinning of nails. What microscopic finding is observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Max Joseph Space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The histological finding of Max Joseph spaces in lichen planus, correlates with the clinical presentation of flat-topped, violaceous papules.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painful, vesicular rash on his right chest that does not cross the midline. He reports that the rash started as a painful, tingling sensation a few days ago, which was then followed by the eruption of vesicles. He has a history of chickenpox in childhood. On examination, the rash is in a band-like pattern on the thorax, and you notice that it does not cross the midline. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tzanck smear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes zoster (shingles) has multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells.

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-e, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Bindi Leukoderma is caused by which chemical?

options.label: D
options.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:
  • ➤ Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-day history of rapidly evolving rash after experiencing vesicles over his lips. He reports a burning sensation followed by the appearance of concentric erythematous rings on his palms. He denies any recent illness, medication changes, or new exposures. He has a past medical history significant for recurrent herpes labialis. On examination, you note several round lesions with central erythema, intermediate zone of pallor and peripheral erythema, as depicted in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Erythema multiforme

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema multiforme has target lesions, often precipitated by a herpes simplex infection in a patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with no significant past medical history presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic, scaly plaques that have been persisting for several months. She mentions that the rash tends to worsen with stress and cold weather. On examination, you notice well-demarcated, thick, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor aspects of her elbows and knees. Removal of the scale leads to pinpoint bleeding. Which of the following clinical signs is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Auspitz sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales and the positive Auspitz sign, which is pinpoint bleeding following scale removal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with a widespread, itchy rash that started a week after she noticed a single, large, scaly, erythematous patch on her back. She states that the larger patch was followed by multiple smaller, oval lesions that spread centripetally and aligned along the lines of skin tension, also known as the 'Christmas tree pattern.' She denies any recent infections or medication changes and reports that she is otherwise healthy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rosea has herald patch followed by a 'Christmas tree' distribution of secondary annular lesions with peripheral scaling along the lines of skin tension.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to a rash that appeared three days after he developed a fever, cough, and conjunctivitis. On examination, you note a maculopapular rash that started on his face and is now spreading to his trunk and extremities. Along the buccal mucosa, you observe small white spots with an erythematous base. The child has not received his scheduled immunizations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles has systemic symptoms of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and characteristic maculopapular rash, along with pathognomonic Koplik spots, in an unvaccinated child.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with sharply demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales on the extensor surfaces of his elbows and knees. He reports mild itching and worsening of the lesions in cold weather. On physical examination, you note that the scales easily slough off, leaving behind pinpoint bleeding spots. A skin biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathological features is most characteristic of psoriasis?

options.label: A
options.text: Stratum basale shows basal cell degeneration

options.label: C
options.text: Stratum spinosum shows spongiform pustule of Kogoj

options.label: D
options.text: Saw-toothed rete ridges is a feature

questions.correct_answer: C. Stratum spinosum shows spongiform pustule of Kogoj
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stratum spinosum shows spongiform pustule of Kogoj

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis is histologically presented by spongiform pustules of Kogoj in the stratum spinosum, elongation of the rete ridges, and a decreased or absent stratum granulosum.

questions.text: Match the ectopic sebaceous glands listed with their corresponding site: Choose the correct match from the options below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-e

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fordyce spots on the buccal mucosa, Tyson's glands on the prepuce, Meibomian glands on the eyelid margin, and Montgomery's tubercle on the areola.

questions.text: A 24-year-old Asian female presents with concerns about a bluish-gray patch on her face, which has been present since birth. She notes that the lesion has remained stable in size but has become more pigmented over time. On examination, the patch is noted on the skin of her left cheek, extending to the ipsilateral sclera. There is no associated pain, pruritus, or elevation above the level of the surrounding skin. There are no similar lesions elsewhere on her body. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nevus of Ota

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nevus of Ota presents with hallmark bluish-gray pigmentation on the face and involvement of the ipsilateral sclera, a dermal melanocytosis categorized as Ceruloderma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male returns to the clinic with a history of recurrent, localized skin eruptions. He describes the development of a solitary, sharply demarcated, erythematous to violaceous plaque on his lower lip and adjacent facial skin after ingesting over-the-counter pain relievers. The lesion is painful and heals with post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation. He denies any associated fever, itching, or other systemic symptoms. No new topical or dental products have been used. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fixed drug eruption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fixed drug eruption presents with recurrent, well-demarcated, erythematous to violaceous patch at the same site upon re-exposure to a specific drug, typically resolving with post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While scrub typhus , cutaneous anthrax , and brown recluse spider bites can cause necrotic eschar-like lesions, Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) does not typically present with such a skin lesion and should not be considered as a differential in this case.
  • ➤ scrub typhus
  • ➤ cutaneous anthrax
  • ➤ brown recluse spider bites
  • ➤ Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with a several-month history of progressive muscle weakness, particularly when climbing stairs or getting up from a seated position. On examination, you observe a heliotrope rash with periorbital edema, and upon further inspection, you note erythematous, scaly eruptions over her knuckles. Laboratory studies show elevated muscle enzymes, and electromyography reveals evidence of myopathy. Which of the following clinical findings is most specific for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gottron's papules are a specific clinical sign of dermatomyositis, which presents as erythematous, scaly eruptions over the knuckles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents with a several-week history of diarrhea, dermatitis, and general malaise. He reports that the diarrhea is watery, without blood, and the rash primarily affects his forearms and neck, areas that are regularly exposed to sunlight. Upon examination, you note a symmetrical, hyperpigmented, scaly rash in these areas. The patient mentions his diet consists primarily of maize and has been low in variety. Which vitamin deficiency should be primarily considered in this patient's diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Niacin (Vitamin B3)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triad of diarrhea, dermatitis in sun-exposed areas, and dementia are seen in pellagra caused by a deficiency of Niacin (Vitamin B3), especially in populations with a maize-rich diet.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Acne vulgaris is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Topical Retinoids can used in Grade 1 Acne vulgaris

options.label: B
options.text: Acne Vulgaris Characterized by monomorphic skin lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Oral retinoids are the Drug of Choice for Nodulocystic Acne

questions.correct_answer: B. Acne Vulgaris Characterized by monomorphic skin lesions
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acne vulgaris is characterized by monomorphic skin lesions.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acne vulgaris is characterized by polymorphic skin lesions, not monomorphic ones, and involves the pilosebaceous unit with various treatment options available based on severity.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male is brought to the emergency department with a rapidly progressing rash that started shortly after a middle ear infection. His mother reports that the rash began as a localized red area around the navel, which then spread to involve large areas of his body with the skin peeling off in sheets. The baby appears irritable but feeds well, and there are no signs of involvement of the eyes, mouth, or any other mucous membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) in an infant present with extensive epidermal peeling without mucosal involvement, often following a staphylococcal infection.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with several small, rough-surfaced, raised lesions on the fingers. The mother reports that the lesions have been increasing in number over the past few months. The child is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. Which types of human papillomavirus (HPV) are most commonly associated with these cutaneous lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HPV 2, 4, 27

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV types 2, 4, and 27 are the most common causes of verruca vulgaris, the typical presentation of common warts on the skin.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic with a large, darkly pigmented lesion covering a significant portion of his face and scalp, as seen in the image. This congenital lesion has a slightly irregular surface and has been present since birth. His parents are concerned about potential complications associated with this finding. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this type of lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malignant Melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant congenital melanocytic nevi, such as the one depicted in the image, carries an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A woman experienced a hypersensitivity reaction characterized by erythema and inflammation in the scalp area following the application of a cosmetic hair product, as depicted in the image. Which component commonly found in hair dyes is most likely responsible for eliciting this type of skin change?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Para-Phenylenediamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Para-phenylenediamine is a common allergen in hair dyes that can cause allergic contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.

questions.text: In the treatment of fungal nail infections, a particular class of antifungal agents known as morpholines is formulated as a nail lacquer. Which of the following drugs belongs to this class and is used in this formulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amorolfine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amorolfine belongs to the morpholine class and is used as a nail lacquer in the treatment of onychomycosis.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ichthyosis vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe congenital ichthyoses like harlequin ichthyosis and lamellar ichthyosis are associated with membranes around the body, ectropion , and eclabium . Ichthyosis vulgaris , being a milder condition that presents later in life, is an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.
  • ➤ harlequin ichthyosis
  • ➤ lamellar ichthyosis
  • ➤ ectropion
  • ➤ eclabium
  • ➤ Ichthyosis vulgaris

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a rash. She reports that it began with a single large, round, slightly scaly patch, and later, numerous smaller annular lesions appeared on her trunk. These lesions are red with a fine scale and align with the skin tension lines. She experiences mild itching but has no other health issues. She mentions having a respiratory infection a few weeks prior. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rosea is identified by its initial herald patch followed by a distinctive pattern of smaller annular lesions along the lines of skin tension, typically after a viral infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old individual with a new diagnosis of epilepsy is initiated on Lamotrigine therapy, starting at a dose of 50 mg daily. The treating physician plans to increase the dosage incrementally every 1-2 weeks until a maintenance dose of 200 mg/day is achieved. This cautious titration strategy is employed primarily to reduce the risk of which potential adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Skin rash

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Step-up titration of Lamotrigine is a crucial approach to minimize the risk of developing skin rash, including serious conditions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segmental vitiligo includes segmental depigmentation accompanied by leucotrichia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dermatomyositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of heliotrope rash and proximal muscle weakness in a patient with ovarian cancer is highly suggestive of dermatomyositis , an inflammatory condition often associated with malignancy.
  • ➤ heliotrope rash
  • ➤ proximal muscle weakness
  • ➤ ovarian cancer
  • ➤ dermatomyositis

questions.text: A patient comes in with the genital lesions as shown in the image. If scrapings were taken from these lesions, which cellular findings would likely be observed under the microscope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tzanck cells and multinucleate giant cells in scrapings from genital lesions, suggest a diagnosis of herpes genitalis.

questions.text: A child with a familial history of bronchial asthma presents with bilateral, itchy plaques located on the popliteal and cubital fossae, as displayed in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atopic dermatitis is identified by bilateral, itchy eczematous plaques in flexural regions, especially in patients with a personal or family history of atopic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with the appearance of purpura?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urticaria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urticaria is a condition characterized by wheals, not purpura, differentiating it from other conditions that can cause purpuric lesions.

questions.text: A woman with a BMI greater than 30 presents to the dermatology clinic with velvety, hyperpigmented lesions on her skin. Which condition is most commonly associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Velvety hyperpigmented lesions, particularly in a patient with a high BMI, are suggestive of Acanthosis nigricans, which is associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A young male patient with a presentation of petechiae, melena, atopic dermatitis, and a platelet count of 20,000 with small-sized platelets is evaluated. Which diagnostic test should be pursued next to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) WASP gene mutation analysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome presents thrombocytopenia with small-sized platelets, atopic dermatitis, and a tendency to bleed, and pursue WASP gene mutation analysis for confirmation.

questions.text: Match the Eczemas in column A with the characteristic features given in Column B
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is evaluated in the pediatric clinic due to persistent diarrhea, a rash on his face, hands, and feet, irritability, and poor feeding. Physical examination reveals erythematous plaques with pustules and crusting around the mouth, nose, and extremities. Which nutrient deficiency is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency (Acrodermatitis enteropathica) in infants presents with diarrhea, irritability, poor feeding, and a characteristic erythematous rash with pustules and crusting.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with rough, keratotic papules on her elbows and knees, which have become more prominent over the past few months. Her mother reports that the child has been having difficulty seeing in low-light conditions. Physical examination reveals bumpy skin on the extensor surfaces and a bitot's spot on the conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phrynoderma is a skin condition associated with vitamin A deficiency, presenting with rough, keratotic papules on the extensor surfaces and can be associated with night blindness due to the systemic effects of the vitamin deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with multiple, painful, fluid-filled blisters on the skin. The blisters are described as being very thin-walled and easily ruptured with gentle pressure. Oral mucosal involvement is noted with erosions and blisters. A skin biopsy is performed and shows acantholysis with a suprabasal split. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease that presents with flaccid bullae and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, with histology showing suprabasal acantholysis.

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug-induced bullous pemphigoid is a potential side effect of Anti PD-1 immunotherapy, diagnosed by subepidermal blistering and linear C3 and IgG deposits along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options. Alopecia areata Telogen effluvium Androgenic alopecia Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia as conditions that can cause non-scarring alopecia where hair loss does not result in permanent scarring and may be reversible.

questions.text: Assertion: Patients with atopic eczema have more staphylococcal infections Reason: Patients with atopic eczema have barrier dysfunction

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not correct explanation of Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true and Reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false and Reason is true. Both Assertion and Reason are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with atopic eczema have an increased risk of staphylococcal infections due to the compromised barrier function of their skin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about atopic dermatitis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Clinical examination is diagnostic for atopic dermatitis.

options.label: B
options.text: In the infantile phase, the distribution of lesions is on the extensor surfaces.

options.label: C
options.text: The diagnostic criteria for atopic dermatitis were proposed by Hanifin and Rajka.

options.label: D
options.text: Atopic dermatitis is a chronically relapsing dermatosis that is asymptomatic.

questions.correct_answer: D. Atopic dermatitis is a chronically relapsing dermatosis that is asymptomatic.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis is a chronically relapsing dermatosis that is asymptomatic.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atopic dermatitis is a symptomatic, chronically relapsing dermatosis characterized by episodes of intense itching and eczematous lesions, not an asymptomatic condition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with multiple hyperpigmented macules on his trunk. Notably, when one of the lesions is stroked with the rounded end of a pen, an urticarial wheal appears that is restricted to the margins of the macule. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urticaria pigmentosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperpigmented macules that develop urticarial wheals when stroked, a finding known as Darier's sign,is indicative of cutaneous mastocytosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with a history of recurrent seizures and intellectual disability since birth is examined. He was born of consanguineous marriage, and his father has a history of multiple skin lesions. Upon dermatological evaluation, skin findings consistent with a genetic disorder are noted. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common cardiac tumor associated with this condition is cardiac rhabdomyoma.

options.label: B
options.text: Wood's lamp examination is a useful tool in the diagnostic workup of this case.

options.label: C
options.text: The most probable cause of recurrent episodes of hematuria in this patient is renal cell carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: Dental enamel pitting and gingival fibromas can be associated with this condition.

questions.correct_answer: C. The most probable cause of recurrent episodes of hematuria in this patient is renal cell carcinoma.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The most probable cause of recurrent episodes of hematuria in this patient is renal cell carcinoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In tuberous sclerosis complex, renal angiomyolipomas are a common cause of hematuria, not renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Match the dermatological lesions listed in Column A with the appropriate Genodermatoses in Column B:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1e, 2c, 3a, 4b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Among the blistering diseases listed below, which would not demonstrate a positive direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) test? Dermatitis herpetiformis Hailey-Hailey Disease Pemphigus foliaceus Epidermolysis bullosa simplex Bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with intensely pruritic papulovesicular lesions localized on his knees, elbows, upper back, and buttocks. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of the lesions shows granular deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone (BMZ) and dermal papillae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dermatitis herpetiformis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatitis herpetiformis is identified by its clinical presentation of pruritic papulovesicular lesions and the granular deposition of IgA at the basement membrane zone and dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A patient had history of thorn prick while working in a rose garden and later observed linear spread proximally till his shoulder. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this clinical feature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphangitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphangitis is characterized by red streaking on the skin, which represents inflammation of the lymphatic channels, usually occurring secondary to an infectious process spreading from a distal site of injury, such as a thorn prick.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with violaceous plane topped papules associated with Pruritus over wrist and antecubital fossae for 2 months. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. What is the first line of treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Topical steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first line of treatment for lichen planus, characterized by violaceous, flat-topped papules with pruritus, is high-potency topical steroids to reduce skin inflammation and pruritus.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules over his elbow and penis. Histopathological examination (HPE) of the lesions reveals the following feature. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lichen Nitidus (LN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen Nitidus is characterized by tiny, flesh-colored papules that can occur on the flexor surfaces, genitalia, and abdomen, with histopathology showing a localized granulomatous reaction in the dermis.

options.label: C
options.text: Fever usually comes down within 8 hours

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain , and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with white plaques on his lateral tongue that cannot be scraped off. Based on this presentation, which virus is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive sweating and a noticeable odor, particularly after physical activity. On examination, the sweating and odor are most prominent in the underarm area. This condition is likely associated with which of the following glandular structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Eccrine glands in the palms and soles

questions.correct_answer: C. Apocrine glands in the axilla
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apocrine glands in the axilla

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 85-year-old lady presents to dermatology clinic complaining of itchy white plaques affecting her vulva. There is no history of vaginal discharge or bleeding. A similar plaque is also seen on her inner thigh. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lichen Sclerosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen sclerosus is a chronic condition affecting the vulva, characterized by white, itchy plaques and atrophy . It is more common in postmenopausal women and can cause significant discomfort if untreated. The absence of discharge or bleeding and the clinical appearance are key features supporting this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Lichen sclerosus

  • ➤ atrophy
